topic_metadata.title: How to shrink document to output?

posts.name: Johannes Lade
posts.cooked:
I want to generate an image of a single formula. How do I shrink the document size to just fit that formula?

Here is my typst code

#import "@preview/mitex:0.2.4"

#mitex.mitex(`\LARGE{g = 1 + \frac{N}{2} \left( k - 2 - \sum_{i=1}^{k}\frac{1}{n_i}\right)}`)
posts.raw:
I want to generate an image of a single formula. How do I shrink the document size to just fit that formula?

Here is my typst code
```typst
#import "@preview/mitex:0.2.4"

#mitex.mitex(`\LARGE{g = 1 + \frac{N}{2} \left( k - 2 - \sum_{i=1}^{k}\frac{1}{n_i}\right)}`)
```

posts.name: Jan Romann
posts.cooked:
You could use auto for the page height and width like so:

#set page(height: auto, width: auto)

image844×524 22.5 KB

Edit: You can get rid of the surrounding whitespace by adjusting the margins like so:

#set page(height: auto, width: auto, margin: 0pt)

This yields the following result:

image974×230 29.7 KB
posts.raw:
You could use `auto` for the page height and width like so:

```typ
#set page(height: auto, width: auto)
```

![image|690x428](upload://23rIGpsuWEbqS1RK7QAhuGrq29I.png)

Edit: You can get rid of the surrounding whitespace by adjusting the margins like so:

```typ
#set page(height: auto, width: auto, margin: 0pt)
```

This yields the following result:

![image|690x162, 50%](upload://qmwATh3UZpJkfbj1EVv4d3tjnBT.png)

posts.name: Johannes Lade
posts.cooked:
Thanks. I sadly just realized that typst cannot (yet) produce png images but only pdf.

EDIT
This is just wrong. Read below to see how to change output format.
posts.raw:
Thanks. I sadly just realized that typst cannot (yet) produce png images but only pdf.

EDIT
This is just wrong. Read below to see how to change output format.

posts.name: Johannes Lade
posts.cooked: Also it still has a huge margin around the formula.
posts.raw: Also it still has a huge margin around the formula.

posts.name: Jan Romann
posts.cooked:
Hmm, I think you can compile to a png using:

typst compile -f png your-file.typ

You also can get rid of the margin using set page(margin: 0pt) :)
posts.raw:
Hmm, I think you can compile to a png using:

```sh
typst compile -f png your-file.typ
```

You also can get rid of the margin using `set page(margin: 0pt)` :)

posts.name: Johannes Lade
posts.cooked:
Ok, easy fix:

#set page(height: auto, width: auto, margin: 0cm)
posts.raw:
Ok, easy fix:

```typst
#set page(height: auto, width: auto, margin: 0cm)
```

posts.name: Johannes Lade
posts.cooked: oh yeah you are right. Sorry I am a very sporadic user of typst and I tend to forget things. Hopefully this thread will help someone else in the future.
posts.raw: oh yeah you are right. Sorry I am a very sporadic user of typst and I tend to forget things. Hopefully this thread will help someone else in the future.

posts.name: Johannes Lade
posts.cooked:
Nice trick to generate multiple formula images from one document. Add a #pagebreak() between each formula.

// example.typ

#set page(height: auto, width: auto, margin: 0cm)

$ f(x) = f(n-1) + f(n-2) $

#pagebreak()

$ v^2 / 2 + g z + p / rho = "constant" $

#pagebreak()

$ E = m c^2 $

and then you can generate multiple output pictures with this command:

typst c example.typ example_{n}.png

Note that you don’t need to specify -f when you explicitly write the name of the output file because you need to specify the file extension anyway.

Output:

example_11086×91 34.8 KB

example_2952×225 39.6 KB

I couldn’t add the third image because I am a new user on the forum but you get the idea.
posts.raw:
Nice trick to generate multiple formula images from one document. Add a `#pagebreak()` between each formula.
```typst
// example.typ

#set page(height: auto, width: auto, margin: 0cm)

$ f(x) = f(n-1) + f(n-2) $

#pagebreak()

$ v^2 / 2 + g z + p / rho = "constant" $

#pagebreak()

$ E = m c^2 $
```
and then you can generate multiple output pictures with this command:
```bash
typst c example.typ example_{n}.png
```
Note that you don't need to specify `-f` when you explicitly write the name of the output file because you need to specify the file extension anyway.

Output:
![example_1|690x57, 50%](upload://6uD2aHnyXZHYvc0nrbkRRsjxXH3.png)

![example_2|690x163, 50%](upload://7W6j6jgCG2XzQU26FCzXDC6UvjI.png)
I couldn't add the third image because I am a new user on the forum but you get the idea.

posts.name: Jan Romann
posts.cooked: Very nice! :) Thanks for adding that information to the thread.
posts.raw: Very nice! :) Thanks for adding that information to the thread.

posts.cooked:
Instead of manual page breaks, you can also do this:

#set page(height: auto, width: auto, margin: 0cm)
#show math.equation: page

$ f(x) = f(n-1) + f(n-2) $

$ v^2 / 2 + g z + p / rho = "constant" $

$ E = m c^2 $
posts.raw:
Instead of manual page breaks, you can also do this:

```typ
#set page(height: auto, width: auto, margin: 0cm)
#show math.equation: page

$ f(x) = f(n-1) + f(n-2) $

$ v^2 / 2 + g z + p / rho = "constant" $

$ E = m c^2 $
```

posts.name: Johannes Lade
posts.cooked: Sadly, this doesn’t quite work as intended as this will create an empty page at the end of the file and therefore also an empty image when rendering to svg or png.
posts.raw: Sadly, this doesn't quite work as intended as this will create an empty page at the end of the file and therefore also an empty image when rendering to svg or png.

posts.cooked: I think that’s an issue that’s fixed in the next release (0.12), you can give it a try with the release candidate…
posts.raw: I think that's an issue that's fixed in the next release (0.12), you can give it a try with the release candidate...
